questions.text: During the primary survey of a trauma patient in the emergency department, which of the following injuries is not classified as life-threatening under the category of “breathing” problems?

A 45-year-old man is found unconscious after a fall from a ladder. In the emergency department, his eyes do not open even in response to pain; he is making incomprehensible sounds, and he exhibits abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.explanation:
Category

Response

Score

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

3

2

None

1

2

None

1

Obeys commands

6

5

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision with unstable vitals and multiple injuries. Which trauma severity score is most appropriate for predicting his likelihood of survival?
questions.correct_answer: C. Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS)
questions.explanation:
Score

Key Parameters

Application

ISS

Anatomical injury in body regions (AIS system)

Measures overall injury severity

RTS

GCS, Respiratory Rate, Systolic BP

Physiological response to trauma

TRISS

Combination of ISS, RTS, and Age

Predicts survival probability in trauma

MESS

Limb ischemia, shock, age, and energy of injury

Predicts need for amputation in limb trauma

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents to the ED after a head injury sustained in a motor vehicle accident. He briefly lost consciousness at the scene but was alert and oriented upon arrival. A few hours later, he becomes progressively drowsy, and his right pupil is dilated. A CT scan shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Epidural Hematoma (EDH)

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

(Option A)

Mechanism
  • Rupture of an artery, often the middle meningeal artery, usually due to a skull fracture, commonly in the temporal bone.

Two contexts:

  • High-energy injury: Rupture of cortical surface vessels.
  • Low-energy injury: Venous bleeding, common in older adults on anticoagulants.

Clinical Presentation
  • Classic: Transient loss of consciousness, lucid interval, rapid neurological decline.
  • Headaches are common.
  • Brain compression signs: Contralateral hemiparesis, reduced consciousness, ipsilateral pupillary dilation.
  • Variable presentation depending on injury severity and timing.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure: Headache, reduced consciousness, focal neurological deficits.

CT Appearance

Lentiform (lens-shaped or biconvex) hyperdense lesion between the skull and the brain.



 

Diffuse concave hyperdense (acute), isodense (subacute), or hypodense (chronic) lesions over the brain surface, often crossing suture lines.


 

Management

Neurosurgical emergency; requires immediate evacuation, usually by craniotomy.

Depends on size, location, and clinical status:

1. Large or worsening hematomas: Urgent evacuation by craniotomy or craniectomy.

2. Smaller, stable bleeds: Conservative management initially, with surgery if needed.

Summary

EDH often follows a predictable course with a lucid interval.

SDH has a more variable presentation and distinct CT appearance.

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman sustains a stab wound in the neck that is located just above the cricoid cartilage but below the angle of the mandible. The injury is causing severe bleeding, and there is concern about the potential involvement of vital neck structures. Which neck zone is most relevant for assessing potential injury to major blood vessels and the trachea in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Zone of Neck

Location

Contents

Features

Zone I

(Option A)

Between the clavicles and the cricoid cartilage.
  • Innominate vessels
  • Origin of the common carotid artery
  • Subclavian vessels and vertebral artery
  • Brachial plexus
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • The apex of the lung
  • Thoracic duct
  • Difficult surgical exposure and access due to the clavicle and bony thoracic inlet structures.

Zone II

Between the cricoid cartilage and the angle of the mandible.
  • Carotid and vertebral arteries
  • Internal jugular veins
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Largest zone
  • Most commonly injured
  • Relatively easy access for clinical examination and surgical exploration.

Zone III

(Option C)

Between the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull
  • Distal carotid and vertebral arteries
  • Pharynx
  • Less accessible to physical examination
  • Difficult to explore surgically.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man presents to the ED after a fall from a height. He is in severe respiratory distress, with rapid breathing. An x-ray film was taken of the chest which revealed the following. His blood pressure is rapidly dropping. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Tracheal deviation towards the opposite side

questions.text: A 30 y/o male is admitted after a motorcycle accident with abdominal trauma. The doctor decides to perform initial imaging tests. Which statement about FAST, eFAST, and DPL is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: eFAST can detect >100 mL of free blood in the abdomen and thoracic cavities.

options.label: B
options.text: FAST is reliable for assessing retroperitoneum and detecting injuries to hollow viscus.

options.label: C
options.text: DPL is valuable in resource-limited settings and detects blood or contaminants in the abdomen.

options.label: D
options.text: FAST and eFAST do not determine the specific nature or extent of injuries.

questions.correct_answer: B. FAST is reliable for assessing retroperitoneum and detecting injuries to hollow viscus.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male is undergoing damage control surgery after sustaining severe abdominal injuries in a construction accident. After rapid haemorrhage control, he is moved to the ICU for further resuscitation. What is the main focus during the ICU stage of damage control surgery?

options.label: D
options.text: Selection of the Next Surgical Procedure

questions.explanation:
Stages of Damage Control Surgery

Stage

Intervention

1

Patient Selection

2

Control of haemorrhage and contamination

3

Resuscitation in ICU

4

Definitive Surgery

5

Abdomen closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery

Phase

Intervention

Steps

1

Recognition and Decision-making

Intubation, early rewarming, and prompt movement to operation theatre

2

Immediate Laparotomy

Control of bleeding, abdominal packing, and temporary abdominal closure

3

Intensive Care Unit

Ongoing resuscitation and normalization of physiological and biochemical parameters (Option B)

4

Re-Exploration

Definitive repair of all injuries (Options A & C ruled out)
